title_1.eng: Get down on your child’s level

text_1.eng: This helps you to enter into your child’s world, and to notice what they are doing.

title_2.eng: Let your child take the lead

text_2.eng: Let your child choose the activity. You are there to follow them and meet them where they are (as long as it is safe, accept and allow what your child wants to do during this time).

text_3.eng: Pay attention to what your child is doing. Notice what they are playing with. Be curious about what they might be thinking and feeling.

title_4.eng: Don’t try to change what they are doing, interfere or interrupt

text_4.eng: Don’t ask too many questions. It is also important to not criticize or correct them or give suggestions for what they should be doing differently.

title_5.eng: Respond to what they are doing

text_5.eng: Describe what you see your child is doing. Or mirror what your child is doing.

extra_text.eng:
Before you start:

*   Give it a name (e.g., Marlow&Mom time) and tell your child that you want to play with them / spend special time together
*   Give it a time frame – “let’s play together for the next xx minutes”
*   Reduce the number of distractions and interruptions as much as possible (put your phone away, put the television off, find a time when your other children are doing something else)

outro_text.eng:
It shows your child you are paying attention and that you are interested in them, that what they are doing is important

It shows your child that you value what THEY are doing

It builds your child’s self esteem and makes them feel important

It gives you a chance to learn a lot about your child’s interests and abilities

It strengthens your relationship with your child

text_1.eng: Notice what your child is interested and talk about it / ask them questions

text_2.eng: Notice when your child is losing interest and move on to the next page

text_3.eng: Don’t force your child to take part in the activity. rather try again another time

title_1.eng: Identify activities that you find relaxing and that are important to YOU.

text_1.eng: These are the activities that make you happy and that will replenish your empty cup. If you had an hour to yourself, what would you like to do?

title_2.eng: Make a plan and commit to doing it.

text_2.eng: There will ALWAYS be other things to do, other people and tasks needing your time and attention. So you have to make the time for yourself and stick to your plan. We know it’s hard, but remind yourself that you are important and that the world will not fall apart if you take a break to do something that is important to you.

title_3.eng: Talk to your children and family about this.

text_3.eng: If you say it out loud, your family can help you stick to your plan. Tell your partner / family: “I need 30 minutes to be by myself. When can we make this happen?” Or tell your child: “I know you want me to play with you right now, but I need some time to rest by myself. I know it is hard to wait, but we can play together again after dinner”. This also models to your child that it is important and healthy to look after yourself.
